content: The "Child Support Enforcement Act of 1994" allows for the seizure of lottery winnings, settlements, payouts, and sale of forfeited property to pay child support arrearages. Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include procedures for imposing a lien on winnings from state lotteries or gambling establishments to ensure child support payments are made. The amended Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act includes procedures for withholding child support arrearages from insurance payments or claim settlements until confirmation is received from the State child support agency. The withheld amount is then paid to the agency for distribution. The amended Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act requires suspending insurance payments or claim settlements until confirmation is received from the State child support agency regarding any child support arrearages owed. RESTRICTIONS RELATING TO PROFESSIONAL, OCCUPATIONAL, BUSINESS, AND DRIVER'S LICENSES. Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include procedures where State licensing departments cannot issue or renew licenses for noncustodial parents with outstanding warrants related to child support proceedings. The amended Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act prohibits State licensing departments from issuing or renewing licenses for noncustodial parents with outstanding warrants related to child support proceedings. The hold on the license can only be released with consent from the individual owed child support, a State prosecutor, or a court responsible for enforcement, or after an expedited inquiry and review. The State motor vehicle department cannot issue or renew driver's licenses or vehicle registrations for noncustodial parents with outstanding warrants related to child support proceedings. A temporary license or vehicle registration may be granted to the individual pending compliance with the order or the removal of the warrant. SEC. 4. ATTACHMENT OF BANK ACCOUNTS. Section 466(a) (42 U.S.C. 666(a)), as amended, allows for seizing amounts in bank accounts to satisfy child support arrearages. REPORTING OF CHILD SUPPORT OBLIGATIONS TO CREDIT BUREAUS. Section 466(a)(7) of the Social Security Act is amended to require courts and administrative agencies to report child support orders to consumer reporting agencies. The Social Security Act is amended to require reporting agencies to provide the name and amount of child support obligations. The Social Security Act is amended to hold parents financially responsible for their children if the individual is unable to provide support.
